MR.. CALHOUN AND THE RIP RAP CON
TRACT.-We published on Saturday, The pro.
ceedings Of Congress relative 10 charge made by
T.. MIR, and published in the Alexandria Gazette,
against MIR. Calhoun, relative TO the celebrated Rim
Rap contracts. That our eaders may fully under
stand the causes which have produced this spps al
from the Vice President, we have conceived il ne
cesssry merely TO repuol>h, in connexion al! tha,
has appeared in the newspapers in relation 10 il.
passage in MIR. Cahoun's letter, says the National
Journal may lead some TO suppose ,ha, the charge
OF his having participated in the profits OF the con
tracu, is made By the Alexandra Gazette. A ref
erence to the annexed remarks OF the Editor Of ha,
paper will show that this is incorrect. he sat. ia
squvocally, " for ourselves, we acgrt Mr. Calhoun
OF any participation in the profits Of the contracts
made ny him." 1t ii. Mr.. Mix who makes the ac
eusation; and, as he says, upon the authotily Of
letters in his possession from Col. Vandeyenler


From the .9Lernndria Phsni.r Gaxeite.


Mos, OF our readers, we presume, have either
heard or read OF the celebrated Elijah Mix, whose
name has been so often associated with Castle Cal
houn and the Rip Raps. This distinguished DER
sonage has sgaln made his appearance in the Doll,
ics world, much TO the annoyance however. oi
those who contributed and we're still endeavorino
70 contribute, TO his fortune and CONSEQUENCE. III
has kicked up "a dust in Washington, from which
the whole tribe OF his late associates are tyirc il
every direction, dennuncing him with an intensity
Of bitterness, equae only BY thar Of their previous

FRAUDS ON THE REVENUE.-The Bos
ton Courier says the annexed extract OF letter.
from gentleman at New York. develops some Of
the schemes practised by foreign agents and specu
laors, TO esade our revenue laws and TO enable the
to keep down the rival manufactures OF our country
i is from responsible source, and The facts may Be
relied on,


".Ner Fork, Dpc a. 1896.


There is one ingenious way Of deiraudine the
revenue, practised BY English manufacturers and
their agents here, which ought to be made public
in order that the abuse may be corrected. You
know, however, that it is no part Of my business ia
look after such matters; but il knowledge of The
following facts will be OF service to the munufac,ur
ers OF your state, you at liberty TO make wha,
use OF them you please. Broadcloihs are entered al
our custom House. invoced unfinished cloths,
and from their rough appearance are. with the best
Intentions in the world on the part Of the appraisers,
passed for about one hall what they are wor1h These
cloths are taken to one Of The finishing establishment
OF which there are several belonging to Englishmen
IN New York and there finished at an expense Of
only three or four cents yard, whence ,hey are
carried to the auction room for sale ;,

The preceding letter is most respectfully and ear.
nestly recommended to the serious attention of the
cllzens Of the United States at large, in the hope
pray heaven II may not be yain-of awakine the
sumeering sympsthies OF this great aud rising en-
pre- 10 favor OF one OF the most inter cs,lnp nations
that ever existcd-a nation whose struggle for eve
~ thing dear and sacred to human nature under
almost every possible disadvantage, has ne.
yer been exceeded and but rarely equalled for The
most intiexlbe devotion to country, and The mos,
heroic vaor. The annals Of the world, since ruth
less warfare began to deyour the human race pre-.
sent nothing OF patriotism and bravery more hon
orabe TO our nature than the defence of Missolong
n. Had any Of the nations oi Eurone zealously
espoused the cause Of the Greeks, with two or three
large 'rgatss or vessels o The line they would have
tilumphed long since established thsi- indepen-
dence on firm foundation and taken their rank
among the nations Of the earth. But while all IN.
liberal and enlightened people Of Europe are mos,
eec'dediy favorable TO their cause, and pouring OUT
ardent prayers to heaven for their success The gov
efnmen.s OF that quarter OF the globe, either lock
on with irieid Indifference malignant jealousy, or
coverlly aid their ferocols oppressors. The pow
derm'lls Of Europe a'c employed in manufacturing
po"der-'he loundries in casting cannon and the
shpysrds in building vessels OF war; for the purpose
OF aiding in the determination OF this brave
ha'ion And finally, to cap the Climax or dishonor
and disgrace, the armies OF the Turks are ofceled,
ana 'heir tiests manGusred, by base and recreans
Christians!

MATHEW CAREY, ESQ.


Dear Sir,-I perceive, in q late National Gazette
the report of the doings Of committee raised do,
the relief Of the Greeks; and, as the organ Of ha,
committee, beg leave to address you. In the re.
port alluded to, which / have had an opporlunn,
only TO look over hastily various modes and plans d
relief are suggested, which, doubt not, will re.
ceye due consideration, on the part OF those ID
whom they are referred. My only object in n,tu.
ding upon you, is 10 observe, that received from
Greece, the day before yesterday, accounts Of The
country, which have led me TO think, tha, ,he
amount Of suffering for uant Of food, is equal 10
that produced by The direct operations Of the hos
tile force. One Of the letters have receivedis
from our coun,ryman, Jarvis, who has distinguished
himself in the military service oil the country, and
possesses the confidence Of its government. He
writes as follows -" The Committees for the re-
lief of the Greeks in France, Holland, and Geneva
have sent twelve cargoes of PROVISIONS and an
agent TO superntend their distribution. THIS
HAS PREVENTED THE FINAL STARyA
TlON OF THE COUNTRY!! Let no, the
United States. among so many States and nations,
be Indifferent to the suferings Of this dreadful but
not desperate conflict"


With this letter from Mr.. Jarvis, I received one
ftom Kolocotronl, who has been so prominent from
the commence cement of the revolution as military
chief, and is now at the head OF the Greek forces



written in Romaic. He thus expresses himself on
the assistance received BY his country from other
Dalions;-


"Our Christian brethren throughout the world
sympahi.ing with Greece in her extremity, have
sen. us aid ol various kinds, TO support us in our
holy war From the societies for the relief OF the
Greeks in England, in France, in Switzerland, and
many other countries Of Europe, we have frequent
communications oil articles both OF sus,enance and
war; which have proved a relief to the poverty and
desitution of the Greeks TO whom the foe has left
no agriculture, no commerce, no arts and who,
being exclusively occupied in the struggle, have no
means ct supplying what Is needtul either Tor sub
sis'ence or military operations.


The people Oh America, people OF Christians.
people devoted to liberty, Of whose friendship and
sympathy for Greece We have already received am.
pie proof, are, 10 our great misfortune the iarthest
removed from us. But remote as they are, sir,
the friends OF freedom and The friends of humanity
may yet contribute to The relief of our country
nor will their aid be the less efficient or servceable
particularly IN our present emergency
From this authentic source Of information, am
iec 10 think, dear sir, that great amount OF suffer.
ing might be relieved by the despatch Of vessel
loaded with provisions for his unhappy country.
Many excellent and benevolent persons would CO
operate IN this mode Of aiding the Greeks, who
would object 10 other propositions. An amount Of
iunds, quite inadequate to any efficient military
equipment. would suffice for The purchase Of very
considerable quantity Of food, and its TRANSPORTATION
TO the scene OF distress.


am, Dear Sir, with great respect,


Your Friend and Servant,


EDWARD EVERETT

full articles.headline: shington, 7th Dec. 1926.
full articles.article:
MATHEW CAREY, ESQ.


Dear Sir,-I perceive, in q late National Gazette
the report of the doings Of committee raised do,
the relief Of the Greeks; and, as the organ Of ha,
committee, beg leave to address you. In the re.
port alluded to, which / have had an opporlunn,
only TO look over hastily various modes and plans d
relief are suggested, which, doubt not, will re.
ceye due consideration, on the part OF those ID
whom they are referred. My only object in n,tu.
ding upon you, is 10 observe, that received from
Greece, the day before yesterday, accounts Of The
country, which have led me TO think, tha, ,he
amount Of suffering for uant Of food, is equal 10
that produced by The direct operations Of the hos
tile force. One Of the letters have receivedis
from our coun,ryman, Jarvis, who has distinguished
himself in the military service oil the country, and
possesses the confidence Of its government. He
writes as follows -" The Committees for the re-
lief of the Greeks in France, Holland, and Geneva
have sent twelve cargoes of PROVISIONS and an
agent TO superntend their distribution. THIS
HAS PREVENTED THE FINAL STARyA
TlON OF THE COUNTRY!! Let no, the
United States. among so many States and nations,
be Indifferent to the suferings Of this dreadful but
not desperate conflict"


With this letter from Mr.. Jarvis, I received one
ftom Kolocotronl, who has been so prominent from
the commence cement of the revolution as military
chief, and is now at the head OF the Greek forces



written in Romaic. He thus expresses himself on
the assistance received BY his country from other
Dalions;-


"Our Christian brethren throughout the world
sympahi.ing with Greece in her extremity, have
sen. us aid ol various kinds, TO support us in our
holy war From the societies for the relief OF the
Greeks in England, in France, in Switzerland, and
many other countries Of Europe, we have frequent
communications oil articles both OF sus,enance and
war; which have proved a relief to the poverty and
desitution of the Greeks TO whom the foe has left
no agriculture, no commerce, no arts and who,
being exclusively occupied in the struggle, have no
means ct supplying what Is needtul either Tor sub
sis'ence or military operations.


The people Oh America, people OF Christians.
people devoted to liberty, Of whose friendship and
sympathy for Greece We have already received am.
pie proof, are, 10 our great misfortune the iarthest
removed from us. But remote as they are, sir,
the friends OF freedom and The friends of humanity
may yet contribute to The relief of our country
nor will their aid be the less efficient or servceable
particularly IN our present emergency
From this authentic source Of information, am
iec 10 think, dear sir, that great amount OF suffer.
ing might be relieved by the despatch Of vessel
loaded with provisions for his unhappy country.
Many excellent and benevolent persons would CO
operate IN this mode Of aiding the Greeks, who
would object 10 other propositions. An amount Of
iunds, quite inadequate to any efficient military
equipment. would suffice for The purchase Of very
considerable quantity Of food, and its TRANSPORTATION
TO the scene OF distress.


am, Dear Sir, with great respect,


Your Friend and Servant,


EDWARD EVERETT
